title: Grade 5: United States History I: Migration–American Revolution
subject: Social Studies (2023-)

document.title: Connecticut Elementary and Secondary Social Studies Standards

70994095CA184AC39ED27BB5E7EF2D6E.description:
Identify the contributing factors that underlie multiple and varied points of view about school,
community, and civic issues.

B4CB41320A2347FD916A3CE1CBB95CE8.description:
Illustrate how individuals and groups in the Revolutionary Era and today have and can effect
change (e.g., school, community, and state issues).

F36A6AEBBA844B26B3EC0DB1C97D3BF1.description:
Identify how the political beliefs are represented in the Preamble of the United States
Constitution.

4050040DAC61402FB6DFE5F80A31F908.description:
Explain the role of the Constitution in establishing a system of government in the United
States (e.g., federalism, separation of power, states’ rights).

FD0C7D3FC5B04B869706D7A386DB0B2A.description:
Explain how rules were established at the end of the American Revolution by identifying laws
that promoted and limited personal liberties (e.g., citizenship, property, suffrage).

32FED6EBA6B14C5AB709C8AE4C3D9B18.description:
Examine the origins and purpose of key provisions of the United States Constitution (e.g.,
checks and balances, limited government, popular sovereignty, republicanism, separations of
powers, federalism).

991AD70081714A9080F39E09230178C6.description: The United States Constitution and Civic Participation

16A90BAE237A4CED847F07A3DB927D6E.description: Explain the causes and effects of the Treaty of Paris (e.g., economic, political, social).

BDC1BB0500504D069ADB728B8B826E10.description:
Explain economic interdependence between the New England, Middle, and Southern colonies
during the American Revolution (e.g., trade, efforts to support the continental cause).

E90D72B98D5B4E369B2513679D9901B8.description:
Develop a claim about significant people, places or events in Connecticut during the
American Revolution (e.g., Jonathan Occum, Israel Putnam, Hannah Bunce Watson, Benedict
Arnold, Jordan Freeman).

540ABE361854408D8B09BAFA7E8B2758.description:
Use evidence to develop a claim about the role of Connecticut in the American Revolution
(e.g., Provision State, privateers, Tory and Patriot sentiments).

80E4F8E0A7DD4EE192826FDEFADACBE2.description:
Explain probable causes and effects of major turning points in the American Revolution (e.g.,
Battle of Bunker Hill, Boston Massacre, Saratoga, Valley Forge).

EF37F7264CC64CC5BB57360EC9806A36.description:
Compare information provided by multiple historical sources about the people and events of
the American Revolution (e.g., purpose, maker, significance, fact, opinion, bias).

A37141F22A9B4E39BDFDA343E89E1AEF.description:
Describe how people’s perspectives of the American Revolution are documented in historical
records while noting representation of marginalized voices (e.g., journals, letters, newspaper
articles, pamphlets).

723AADD0EB1741969C62D5FC24A4B80B.description:
Explain why members of the Northeastern Woodland Native American tribes and Black
communities held conflicting views regarding support for the American Revolution.

FD77515E11B14E478B443A8B70B64021.description:
Explain how political and economic beliefs shaped the perspectives held by Patriots and
Loyalists leading to the American Revolution (e.g., individual rights, liberties, representation,
sovereignty, trade and taxation).

5D639EA909AC4E37863341C32AD51CD8.description:
Compare the benefits and costs of governmental and individual choices leading to the
American Revolution (e.g., taxation, homespun movement, right to property).

98977C75E70F47C0BEC8BFC025021A3C.description:
Employ chronological thinking to create timelines comparing the events that led to the
American Revolution (e.g., Seven Years War, Parliamentary acts of taxation, Boston Tea Party,
Boston Massacre, Declaration of Independence).

7012EEFC31B8434D93B65236591D978F.description:
Identify the civic virtues and democratic principles that contributed to the rejection of British
parliamentary rule of the North American colonies.

2A61282D0F7A454FAB13CA8A2A23F7D8.description:
Use evidence to develop a claim about a significant person, place, or event in Connecticut
during the Colonial Era (e.g., Pequot War, Connecticut Witch Trials, Charter Oak).

DE49570C1BC842649351CF379AE06B9A.description:
Compare how political systems were used to make rules that establish community leadership
and protect freedoms for various groups in the Colonial Era (e.g., town hall meetings, tribal
council, juries).

3C2A8C4CCF45426BBADE7D25050558A9.description:
Explain Connecticut’s connection to the transatlantic slave trade (e.g., New London’s deep
water ports, Wethersfield-constructed ship The Tryall).

3EE1ED5C419949A2BD20D9C780316914.description:
Describe resistance movements, both individual and group, against oppression in the
Colonial Era (e.g., Stono Rebellion, Pontiac Rebellion, New English Canaan).

BDF6A713D65D4581B626058852988E6B.description:
Analyze how the abilities and expertise that individuals from the African Diaspora brought
with them to the colonies contributed to economic specialization and trade (e.g., West African
rice cultivation, metal working, and basket weaving).

04301D474B7A4A08A1BD4CDFA785EB58.description:
Compare the reasons for different areas of specialization and trade among individuals and
businesses in New England, Middle, and Southern colonies (e.g., availability and access to
natural resources, hydropower, labor, trade routes).

EDE13D0A620545D794F940E593150A4D.description:
Identify examples of resources used to produce goods and services throughout colonial
settlements in the New England, Middle, and Southern regions (e.g., indentured and slave
labor, natural resources, tools, machines).

AA3238DDA895497D9CD066751F3831AA.description:
Summarize how the Fundamental Orders of Connecticut represented new ideas about
government (e.g., enfranchisement, representative government, consent of the governed).

080EAC9344DA47FAAA8067F3D27E21BF.description:
Explain how the desire for global power and influence led to the exploitation of colonies (e.g.,
Spanish galleon, Triangle Trade, Dutch East India Company, British East India Company).

AE28F2BA493A404EBF2CFF026AC13772.description:
Describe the role of money and currency in trade during the Colonial Era (e.g., British and
Spanish coins, tobacco, wampum, paper money).

C6AD1DB03BB4495596809F99135A7CF0.description:
Use maps to explain the relationship between the location of the New England, Middle,
and Southern colonies, and the environmental characteristics of each region (e.g., New
Amsterdam, New France, Jamestown, Plymouth, Saint Augustine).

25A6DA71ED2943AAB2B0FD8E9ADC142A.description:
Describe gender roles within and among Black, Indigenous, and European communities in
early United States history.

3773F9D2F79C4494817BDF81ED63E41B.description:
Explain how cultural diffusion of agricultural and technological knowledge held by African,
Indigenous, and European communities contributed to North American settlements (e.g., rice
cultivation, open field system, companion planting).

843B83FAFB4940D5A0B982D3766EFBA5.description:
Explain how the culture and experiences of African, Indigenous, and European people
influenced their perspectives during the Age of Exploration (e.g., cultural norms, political
beliefs, trade motives, exploitation).

CE24DA58C20A44E1B1CCD5BE1B216AC6.description:
Describe the causes and effects of European exploration and settlement of the Americas
(e.g., conflict, enslavement, land rights, sovereignty, trade).

1BA78A14C3A442E98DE29E858EEF4E9B.description: Describe the connection between natural resources and human settlement patterns in the Atlantic and Pacific Worlds (e.g., Caribbean, Europe, North America, South America, West Africa).

8267997FD0364CE3A1B77FF8D6B18060.description:
Explain probable causes and effects of the migration of Indigenous peoples and the
formation of Native nations in North America (e.g., archeological evidence).

5DCC71BDC30D463F9D4AFFEC9A2C6F74.description:
Use a range of deliberative and democratic procedures to evaluate and implement
strategies to address problems in classrooms and schools.

567DE763BAA24942B736CEDD2AB9A977.description:
Explain the challenges and opportunities, both present and past, in addressing local,
regional, and global problems in United States history.

66AC38CF960845A1A160E48E0F45FADF.description:
Present a summary of arguments and explanations about early United States history using
print, oral, and digital technologies in classrooms, schools, and out-of-school contexts.

39B08DAA268A4C9694AC95EC47F2FA50.description:
Construct explanations using reasoning, correct sequence, examples, and details with
relevant information and data.

58FFFB953BFF4FFC9B1E87AD9E7CCA3B.description:
Construct arguments using claims and evidence from multiple sources about United
States history.

ECDF60AD20934E65BE5E2CA1ADB74793.description: Communicate Conclusions and Take Informed Action

A1F135D6CE4C4E55A0440AAB69F5C79F.description:
Use evidence to develop claims in response to a compelling question by using evidence
related to early United States history.

A8E6AAD1ED3A4274808F1D770FA4567C.description:
Identify evidence response to a compelling question while determining among fact and
opinion to determine the credibility of multiple sources.

FA078D58440B45279FD50A3C4C2699EE.description:
Gather relevant evidence from multiple sources about a person, event, or issue in United
States history while using the origin, structure, and context to guide selection.

CE7B42CFCA64404D8E4D07E4A784A60A.description:
Apply disciplinary knowledge and practices to demonstrate an understanding of United
States history content.

5ED8C71A9CE244C6A5D7F8A6AE79D586.description:
Determine the kinds of sources that will be helpful in answering compelling and
supporting questions, taking into consideration the different opinions people have about
how to answer the questions.

5C9599470A22472EB1C76FB2CF632CB8.description:
Explain how supporting questions help answer compelling questions in an inquiry about
United States history.

E8E49F0073C84F758F2C76B40BA5A28E.description:
Identify concepts, ideas, and interpretations associated with compelling and supporting
questions about early United States history.
